item.title: [pointerevents3] Incorrect note regarding boundary crossing events for elements with captured pointers
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/setPointerCapture

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The note at the beginning

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The note says that:

When pointer capture is set, pointerover, pointerout, pointerenter, and pointerleave events are only generated when crossing the boundary of the capture target. This has the effect of suppressing these events on all other elements.

However, this is not the case, and boundary crossing events are suppressed when a pointer is captured any element.

What did you expect to see?

The opposite of what is says. No boundary crossing events are fired when a pointer is captured by said element.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Issue was seen with touch inputs, which work like so:

  1. Upon pointerdown on an element, the pointer is captured by the element implicitly for touch inputs 1.
  2. When a pointer is captured by a target:
    • The pointer is considered to be always inside the boundaries of the capturing element 2
    • invocation of hit-testing is suppressed 1
  3. Therefore, no pointerout event is fired

This behavior can be confirmed in this demo

  1. Upon touching #target (the green square), pointer is automatically captured by that element.
  2. No pointerleave/pointerout events are fired unless pointer capture is cancelled explicitly by uncommenting lines 4-7

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-view-1, dom, pointerlock-2, pointerevents3, fullscreen, DOM-Parsing] Content bug: Implementation of the `mode` options for `Element.attachShadow()` in code example could be refined
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

Context: References > Web APIs > Element > Element.attachShadow()

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attachShadow

Specific page section or heading?

  • Heading: Parameters
    https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attachShadow#parameters

What is the problem?

It seems the code example/demonstration is missing some information.

  • For the string mode under the parameter init, the options open and closed aren't included in the example.
  • Or it's left for the reader to figure it out. :)

What did you expect to see?

  • I came across the following code this.attachShadow({ mode: "open" }); for a customElements that I am using in a project.
  • The examples and documentation in MDN seemed close enough. Being fairly new to JavaScript, I didn't understand why "open" and "closed" weren't mentioned directly inside the example.

Did you test this? If so, how?

N.A.

item.title: [cssom-view-1, notifications, dom, service-workers-1, pointerevents3] Better naming of pages
item.content:encoded:
A big step forward was made in #8351, but I'd like to propose this rule to page naming:

  1. If the item is available on the global, use the name. Eg:
    • ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.skipWaiting becomes skipWaiting.
  2. If the item is typically reached via properties reachable from the global, use that property chain, omitting the global.
    • Document.querySelector becomes document.querySelector.
    • CacheStorage.match becomes caches.match.
  3. If the item is an instance method/property, use the constructor name with the first set of caps lower-cased + the property name.
    • Element.getBoundingClientRect becomes element.getBoundingClientRect.
    • HTMLElement.offsetHeight becomes htmlElement.offsetHeight.
  4. If the item is a static method/property, use the constructor name + the property name.
    • Notification.requestPermission remains Notification.requestPermission.
  5. Otherwise, just use the name.
    • PointerEvent remains PointerEvent
